column4: is the largest city in the German federal state of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania and lies in the Mecklenburgian part of the state
column5: close to the border with Pomerania. With around 208
column7: it is the third largest city on the German Baltic coast after Kiel and Lübeck
column8: the eighth largest city in the area of former East Germany

column1: Rostock stands on the estuary of the River Warnow into the Bay of Mecklenburg of the Baltic Sea. The city stretches for about 16 km (10 mi) along the river
column2: that flows into the sea in the very north of the city
column3: between the boroughs of Warnemünde and Hohe Düne. The city center lies further upstream
column4: in the very south of the city. While most of Rostock's inhabitants live on the western side of the Warnow
column5: the area east of the river is dominated by the port
column6: industrial estates and the forested Rostock Heath. The city's coastline east and west of the river mouth is relatively undeveloped
column7: with long sandy beaches prevailing. The name of the city and of the river are of Slavic origin.

column1: Rostock is the economic center of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania and the state's only regiopolis. The port of Rostock is the fourth largest port in Germany after the North Sea ports of Hamburg
column2: Bremen/Bremerhaven and Wilhelmshaven
column3: and the largest port on the German Baltic coast. The ferry routes between Rostock and Gedser in Denmark as well as Trelleborg in Southern Sweden are among the busiest between Germany and Scandinavia. Rostock–Laage Airport lies in a rural region southeast of the city.

column1: In the 11th century Polabian Slavs founded a settlement at the Warnow river called Roztoc (*ras-tokŭ
column2: Slavic for "fork of a river"); the name Rostock is derived from that designation.

column1: During the first partition of Mecklenburg following the death of Henry Borwin II of Mecklenburg in 1226
column2: Rostock became the seat of the Lordship of Rostock

column5: 000 inhabitants and the largest city in Mecklenburg. Ships for cruising the Baltic Sea were constructed in Rostock. The formerly independent fishing village of Warnemünde at the Baltic Sea became a part of Rostock in 1323

column1: At the end of the 15th century
column2: the dukes of Mecklenburg succeeded in enforcing their rule over the town of Rostock
column3: which had until then been only nominally subject to their rule and essentially independent. They took advantage of a riot known as Domfehde
column4: a failed uprising of the impoverished population. Subsequent quarrels with the dukes and persistent plundering led ultimately to a loss of the city's economic and political power.

column1: In 1565 there were further clashes with Schwerin that which had far-reaching consequences. Among other things
column2: the nobility introduced a beer excise that favoured the dukes. John Albert I advanced on the city with 500 horsemen
column3: after Rostock had refused to take the formal oath of allegiance
column4: and had the city wall razed (slighted) in order to have a fortress built. The conflict did not end until the first Rostock Inheritance Agreement of 21 September 1573
column5: in which the state princes were guaranteed hereditary rule over the city for centuries and recognizing them as the supreme judicial authority; this bound Rostock for a long time. The citizens razed (or slighted) the fortress the following spring.

column1: From 1575 to 1577 the city walls were rebuilt
column2: as was the Lagebusch tower and the Stein Gate
column3: in the Dutch Renaissance style. The inscription sit intra te concordia et publica felicitas ("You enter a state of harmony and happiness")
column4: can still be read on the gate
column5: and refers directly to the conflict with the Duke. In 1584 the Second Rostock Inheritance Agreement was enforced
column6: which resulted in a further loss of former city tax privileges. At the same time
column7: these inheritance contracts put paid to Rostock's ambition of achieving imperial immediacy

column1: The strategic location of Rostock provoked the envy of its rivals. Danes and Swedes occupied the city twice
column2: first during the Thirty Years' War (1618–48) and again from 1700 to 1721. Later in the early 19th century
column3: the French
column4: under Napoleon
column5: occupied the town for about a decade until 1813. In nearby Lübeck-Ratekau
column7: who was born in Rostock and who was one of few generals to fight on after defeat at the Battle of Jena
column8: surrendered to the French in 1806. This was only after furious street fighting in the Battle of Lübeck
column9: in which he led some of the cavalry charges himself. By the time of the surrender
column10: the exhausted Prussians had neither food nor ammunition.

column2: the Nazi Party began to gain among Rostock's voters
column3: many of whom had suffered economic hardship during the 1920s. In elections in the summer 1932
column4: when the Nazis achieved 37.3 percent
column5: their greatest national showing in a free election
column6: they polled 40.3 percent in Rostock. A year later
column7: after the Nazi seizure of power and the suppression of other political parties
column8: the Rostock city council (Stadtrat) was composed entirely of Nazis. During Kristallnacht on 10 November 1938
column9: the synagogue in Rostock's Augustenstrasse was destroyed by arson and dozens of Jews were beaten and imprisoned.

column1: Feverish rearmament by the Nazi regime boosted Rostock's industrial importance in the late 1930s
column2: and employment soared at the Heinkel and Arado factories

column2: Rostock was subjected to repeated and increasingly heavy bombing attacks
column3: especially by the British Royal Air Force. Targets included the Heinkel and Arado plants and the shipyard
column4: but churches and other historic structures in the city centre were also heavily damaged
column5: among them the 14th-century Nikolaikirche (St Nicholas Church) and Jakobikirche (St Jacob's Church). The ruins of the latter were torn down in 1960.

column1: The city was eventually captured by the Soviet 2nd Belorussian Front on 2 May 1945 during the Stettin-Rostock offensive operation.

column2: Rostock – now in the German Democratic Republic – became East Germany's largest seaport. The state expanded the national shipyards in the district of Warnemünde. The city's population
column3: boosted in part by resettled ethnic German refugees who had been expelled from territories in the east
column4: increased in the GDR years to a peak of 260
column5: 000. Following the reunification of Germany in 1990
column6: Rostock lost its privileged position as the No. 1 port of the GDR
column7: and the city's population declined to about 200

column1: Rostock is located nearly centrally on Mecklenburg-Vorpommern's Baltic Sea coast. The city is crossed by the Warnow.

Rostock stretches 21.6 km (13.4 mi) from the Baltic Sea to the south and 19.4 km (12.1 mi) from east to west.

column1: Rostock can be reached by motorway (Autobahn) A 1 from Hamburg via Lübeck on A 20 and by A 19 from Berlin and A 20 from Stettin in Poland.
